You, if you break my heart I’ll go
 But I’ll be back again

There is a slight bit of obsession in lyrics like these. Instead of looking at John as a stalker (Coincidentally his relationship with Yoko Ono began with her stalking him!), It’s better to look at him as being determined like Diogenes who desired to learn from the Antisthenes. Antisthenes refused and even had to beat him off with stick, but Diogenes came right back and said:

Strike, for you will find no wood hard enough to keep me away from you, so long as I think you’ve something to say.



His determination softened the heart of Antisthenes who then took him to be his pupil.

This time, I will try to show that I’m
 Not trying to pretend

This line displays the catch-22 that comes with human feelings. He is going to have to try to show that he’s not trying to pretend.

If she thinks he is trying to pretend, his trying not to pretend will seem just as false! What a crazy pickle love is!

You know if you break my heart I’ll go
 But I’ll be back again
 ’Cause I told you once before goodbye
 But I came back again

It sounds as if John is trying to make himself a nuisance, like the cat that came back the very next day! John has always taken a much more jealous and possessive approach towards love than Paul McCartney:

John was always on the run, running for his life. He was married; whereas none of my songs would have ‘catch you with another man’. It was never a concern of mine, at all, because I had a girlfriend and I would go with other girls; it was a perfectly open relationship so I wasn’t as worried about that as John was.

I thought that you would realize
 That if I ran away from you

The foundation for this song was built off of the chord structure for Del Shannon’s classic song “Runaway”

This may be John Lennon’s concealed homage to Del:

I’ll Be Back is me completely. My variation of the chords in a Del Shannon song
